poem:
"Of Battles and Bodegas"

Siren wails in 
the heart of the village -
The fruit seller sighs,
fresh oranges no longer golden.

Tesco,
a mighty river,
flooding the pathways of commerce.

Down the alley,
the corner store man grieves,
his shelves bleed scarcity.

Cornering life's essentials,
seeds in the clasp of giants -
A bitter harvest
under the supermarket sky.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Tesco accused of using cash and carry to ‘squeeze’ village stores out of business Village stores have sounded the alarm over what they claim is a battle for survival, accusing the supermarket group Tesco of using its cash-and-carry arm to “squeeze” them out of business by restricting supplies and deliveries of groceries. Independent retailers, many of them also running the local post office, have told the Guardian that a series of changes recently introduced by". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
